Lieutenant Dick Best.Action: Stares out at the ocean, focusing intently, speaking seriously about impending war without engaging warmly with fellow pilot Dickinson.
Wears his pilot jacket confidently and is described as possibly the top pilot in the Navy who knows his capabilities.
Firmly states 'War is coming' indicating awareness and preparedness.
Does not respond to Dickinson's skepticism, showing focused seriousness.
Checks on Miller's well-being and offers reassurance despite Miller's nervousness.
Jokes teasingly with Dickinson about a shark biting him off.
Expresses a serious and somewhat stern mood about the coming war and mission precautions.
Recognized as the senior pilot and XO of Bombing Six, indicating leadership and skill.
Mentioned by Admiral Halsey as 'full of piss and vinegar,' implying confidence and spirited energy.
Glances at Murray to acknowledge his fear without directly confronting it, allowing Murray to maintain composure.
Keeps the likely death of his friend Mr. Dickinson to himself and focuses on his job without outward emotional display.
Speaks with a clear edge and frustration over Lindsey's radio, expressing concern for untrained pilots' safety.
Leads the way back by dropping smoke bombs and turning on running lights, offering clear guidance to Murray despite the dangerous situation.
Uses dry humor ('You better hope so. Because otherwise we're all going for a swim.') to ease tension for a nervous Murray.
Expresses frustration with intelligence personnel using harsh language ('Those bastards in intelligence couldn't find their ass with two hands and a flashlight').
Confronts a superior officer Lindsey aggressively about his failure and irresponsibility, demonstrating confidence and a no-nonsense attitude in a high-stress situation.
Expresses frustration and anger toward intelligence failures and poor leadership choices, showing situational awareness but impulsiveness.
Focuses criticism on Lindsey’s cowardice and lack of accountability during a critical moment, which indicates perceptiveness and prioritization of mission readiness.
Stands silently with McClusky, sharing a moment of somber reflection on the loss of comrades, showing a respectful and subdued demeanor.
Responds briefly and factually about his roommate Cliff, without showing overt emotional expression or consolation, maintaining a reserved tone.
Half-smiles with relief upon seeing Dickinson, then quickly masks feelings with a poker face.
Shares a moment of pained silence with Dickinson for their fallen comrade Miller.
Rushed to embrace Ann Best tightly, shows affection and concern.
Speaks apologetically to Ann when explaining duty-related absence from home.
Keeps composure and acknowledges his wife's bravery under fire.
Expresses frustration and anger explicitly when facing bad news about a comrade.
Attempts to proactively protect family by suggesting evacuation to safer location.
Accepts his wife's firm refusal decisively and without argument.
Shows momentary surprise or being off-balance by wife’s firm denial.
Holds hands with Ann, tries to contain his grief silently during the funeral ceremony.
Cant find the words to respond to Sarah's statement about loss and danger.
Nods with understanding and respect when Sarah states the importance of family and attending funerals despite the pain.
Appears morose and somber upon hearing about critical war developments (Wake Island fallen), showing emotional impact.
Speaks out to eulogize a fallen friend despite hating public speaking, tells a personal, fond story about the friend, including humorous and honest details.
Makes a teasing, somewhat harsh jab at another speaker but does so in good-natured way, with the group responding positively.
Expresses frustration at the abandonment of Marines defending Wake Island, showing empathy and moral concern.
Speaks fondly and sincerely about his deceased friend Cliff, showing sadness and warmth by honoring his memory and expressing personal connection.
Raises a toast to Cliff with heartfelt words, uniting the group in shared respect and camaraderie.
Jokes warmly and optimistically about future camaraderie and sharing stories, indicating friendly and hopeful nature.
Calls out to Admiral Nimitz with enthusiasm and eagerness to fight, demonstrating loyalty and spirited friendliness toward leadership.
Displays emotional depth and respect for fallen comrades while maintaining composure and camaraderie in a difficult moment.
Confidently identifies the new commander by recognizing the admiral's flag and assessing the situation quickly.
Expresses eagerness and motivation to engage the enemy boldly without hesitation.
Questions intelligence about enemy carriers, showing skepticism but trust in judgment ('The same group of geniuses who blew Pearl Harbor?')
Engages with Murray in a straightforward, calm manner ('Morning, sir. What's the plan?')
Questions intelligence report about enemy carriers, showing skepticism and awareness of enemy capability.
Prepares calmly and confidently for the mission, addressing his wingman with clear instructions.
Plans to go in last to clean up remaining targets, showing strategic thinking and confidence.
Replies to Murray's concern about being shot down with a confident, no-nonsense attitude focused on fighting rather than fear.
Shrugs off Murray's uncertainty and proceeds to cockpit without hesitation, showing focus and decisiveness.
Encourages gunner Murray to keep firing despite danger.
Calms Murray by downplaying the fire as just gasoline to reduce his fear.
Shrugs off damage to his plane with humor, showing resilience but little emotional engagement with Murray’s fear.
Comments matter-of-factly on the gunners being too excited and inexperienced, showing a restrained, professional demeanor without hostility.
Comments insightfully on the inexperience of the ship’s gunners and their poor marksmanship during the air raid, demonstrating understanding of tactical realities.
Remains standing calmly and professionally on the flight deck under immediate threat, showing composure and confidence in a high-stress situation.
Calculates bomb trajectories under pressure and communicates situation calmly.
Identifies and understands an incoming threat that most others can't effectively counter due to positioning of AA guns.
Helplessly watches the bomber's approach without direct intervention.
Rushes up to assist the fire crew with Dickinson to spray water on the stricken plane, showing concern and proactive help.
Rushing up promptly to check on fellow pilot Bruno after the attack, coordinating quickly with the fire crew.
Shows composed, quick reaction during and after the encounter with the Japanese bomber, suggesting confidence in crisis.
No explicit direct action in the excerpt to showcase particular skill or decision-making; mostly observational presence.
Holds the door open for Ann as she exits the car.
Smiles and takes Ann's arm, leading her toward the hotel's entrance.
Rolls his eyes at the boisterous group of torpedo bombers and USO women cheering.
Described by McClusky as 'a rock out there' in combat.
Ann declares him 'the best pilot in the fleet.'
Best's impatience with others who aren't as capable as he is, per Dickinson's comment.
Best’s sarcastic and dismissive comment to Layton of Fleet Intelligence, indicating confidence but possibly a lack of diplomatic skill.
Compliments the flyboys on their efforts and acknowledges their contribution to the war effort.
Tells the bartender to keep the change, showing generosity.
Offers his hand to Ann and dances with her, sharing an intimate, tender moment.
Gently smooths his daughter's covers and kisses her forehead before going to bed, showing care and affection.
Slaps a five-dollar bill on the bar and confidently handles the situation after a social slight, showing composure and self-assurance.
Leads his team with a clear sense of purpose ('trying to win this war'), demonstrating focus and determination.
Engages warmly and confidently in social situations (dances with Ann), showing emotional balance that supports overall competence.
No indication of confusion, hesitation, or failure to act in the excerpt; maintains composure and appropriate social and personal behavior.
Abruptly bursts into the pilot ready room and gives a blunt, no-nonsense speech to new pilots without preparation or warmth.
Acknowledges the sacrifice of predecessors and the harsh realities of war, but refuses to coddle the new pilots, emphasizing toughness over encouragement.
Tells pilots to get into rotation ASAP and not to screw up, then leaves abruptly.
Tells new pilots they need to qualify landings urgently and not to screw up, showing confidence and setting clear expectations before launch.
Seeks to include Willie West in the pilot rotation despite initial doubts.
Acknowledges the need for less experienced pilots to learn by doing, showing understanding and support.
Shows dissatisfaction with the situation but does not criticize Bruno Gaido's voluntary support, indicating respect and tolerance.
Evaluates a pilot who barely succeeds and insists they be kept in the rotation to gain experience despite risks.
Questions the lack of a radioman for a pilot, signaling awareness of safety and operational protocols.
Shows concern for Admiral Halsey by asking if he is okay.
Receives promotion to skipper and responds with a respectful, speechless salute, showing humility and readiness to take responsibility.
Halsey promotes Best from second in command to skipper of Bombing Six, entrusting him with greater responsibility during a critical moment.
Receives the promotion with a crisp salute, indicating disciplined acceptance of new responsibilities.
Warns Willie about the upcoming scouting mission and reminds him to listen carefully to altitude counts to avoid blackout.
Expertly manages a near-crash situation, fighting the stall and safely aborting the takeoff.
Calmly instructs to abort takeoff immediately to protect crew safety.
Responds humbly to Nimitz despite emotional exhaustion, saying 'We all did our duty, sir.'
Shares a tender moment with Ann, pulling her into his arms and seeking quiet time with family.
Shows a haunted, hollow expression and avoids elaborating on personal pain, appearing emotionally distant.
Pours a heavy slug from his flask into Gay's glass and offers to buy him a drink, acknowledging the hardships faced by torpedo bomber crews.
Shrugs and shows visible relief upon realizing Yorktown survived, expressing quiet hope and optimism.
Meticulously inspects the plane alone in the hangar late at night, showing care and responsibility without seeking attention.
Responds to the watch officer's question patiently and honestly, showing sincerity and approachability.
Best's quiet confidence reassures the watch officer, indicating calm and assured demeanor in a tense situation.
Encourages Dickinson to eat before a long day, showing concern for others' wellbeing.
Shares a personal and somber story about Cliff Janz to bond with others and acknowledge loss.
Acknowledges harsh realities openly without sugarcoating, showing sincerity.
Expresses confidence in his comrades and emphasizes brotherhood.
Refuses to turn back despite bad oxygen mix, insists on leading the squadron personally.
Organizes and communicates attack plans clearly and confidently to his squadron.
Quickly assesses the enemy carrier formation from above and directs focus on specific targets.
Commands wingmen to stay close during a dangerous dive, maintaining formation despite confusion.
Reassures and encourages wingman Murray despite the danger, showing commitment and solidarity.
Jokes with wingman Kroeger to lift morale before attack.
Focuses intensely on mission to the point of risking crash on enemy carrier.
Ignores co-pilot Murray's urgent plea to drop the bomb early, remaining focused and disciplined to ensure the bombing accuracy.
Successfully scores a direct hit on enemy carrier Akagi, followed by co-pilot Murray's exuberant celebration.
Maintains focus on the bombsight despite heavy anti-aircraft fire and Murray’s urgent calls to drop the bomb early.
Executes a precise dive bomb run, pulling out at the last moment to avoid crashing into the carrier.

Wrestles the plane skillfully through flak bursts, pulls up abruptly to avoid danger, flies close enough over a destroyer to observe enemy gunners, and maintains situational awareness by scanning the horizon for threats.
Waves off a sailor's concern about his health and continues forward despite coughing and obvious strain.
Quietly acknowledges the likely loss of a fellow pilot (Dickinson) with a pilot updating the status board.
Encourages exhausted pilots to continue the mission despite heavy losses and fatigue.
Encourages Murray to strap up and go back out on the mission despite Murray's fear, showing resolve but somewhat dismissive of Murray's feelings.
Listens to Murray's fears and pain, acknowledges the uncertainty and danger honestly without false bravado.
Expresses his own vulnerability and personal desires (wants to go home, see family), connecting sincerely with Murray.
Offers to find someone else if Murray truly can't fly, respecting Murray's limits and choice.
Encourages Murray sincerely, appealing to his courage and loyalty to the group, expressing hope and confidence in him.
Welcomes Thatch and other displaced pilots warmly, openly inviting them to join him on the next mission, showing camaraderie and inclusiveness.
Encourages Murray to overcome fear and face challenges, showing leadership and emotional intelligence.
Welcomes Thatch and others offering to join his mission, quickly assessing the situation and seizing the opportunity to strengthen his team.
Commands and supports Murray calmly under fire, focuses on mission despite danger.
Ignores Murray's calls for help to maintain focus on bomb run.
Becomes the first and only aviator in history to hit two enemy Carriers in one day.
Warns Thatch jokingly not to fire at him, then shares a friendly exchange with a grin and mock salute.
Shares a sincere moment with Dickinson acknowledging mutual survival after battle.
Gives his flask of whiskey to Murray, saying 'He earned it.'
Coughs violently and appears physically weak, eliciting concern and support from Dickinson.
Recognizes Murray's effort and insists the whiskey be given to him, showing situational awareness and fairness.
Despite illness, manages to exit the cockpit but quickly succumbs to violent coughing and spits blood, indicating physical weakness impairing his immediate operational capability.
Raises a toast honoring lost comrades, openly displays emotion and vulnerability in front of a friend.
Contemplates the losses alone after his friend departs, shows private pain but sustained courage.
Maintains composure and shares a solemn, meaningful toast honoring fallen comrades despite emotional pain.
Contemplates the heavy losses and the grim reality alone, showing emotional awareness and reflection.
Accepts and acknowledges the significance of their achievement (‘We did it’), demonstrating confidence and understanding of impact.
Approaches Layton and offers sincere thanks and acknowledgment for intelligence work, shaking his hand warmly.
Gently calms his daughter Barbera with 'Easy, sweetie' and embraces her and Ann tenderly.
Shows vulnerability by expressing his distress about potentially never flying again and sincerely sharing fears with Ann.
Speaks proudly at the dedication ceremony, showing composure and respect for fallen comrades.
Reflects on the odds and the losses, demonstrating realistic understanding and acceptance of the risks involved in combat flying.
Expresses deep commitment and loyalty to his squadron, willing to fly 'straight into Hell' with his men.
Warns wingman about incoming enemy fire, attempts to protect crew.
Swears in frustration after missing target, orders Miller to break radio silence and get gun working.
Bursts into the radio room taking charge of the situation despite the chaos.
Responds urgently to crisis, shows concern for colleagues, pushes ensign to act quickly
Keeps face expressionless despite bad news about friend, suppresses visible emotion
Responds immediately to confusing and urgent information by questioning and directing communication effectively.
Remains outwardly composed and expressionless despite receiving distressing news about a friend's possible fate.
Demonstrates urgency by commanding the ensign to run with an important message to the admiral, ensuring quick action.
Continues toward his plane despite likelihood his friend is dead; focused on completing mission.

Orders torpedo pilots not trained for night carrier landings to return to Pearl Harbor, overriding a direct order to attempt landing at Enterprise, demonstrating concern for pilot safety and mission success.
Decides to drop smoke bombs, turn on running lights, and lead the way back to the Enterprise despite no homing signal, showing initiative and confidence in navigation.
Responds to Murray's nervousness with dry humor but maintains control, indicating confidence under pressure.
Successfully requests and executes a difficult night landing on the USS Enterprise, demonstrating technical skill and precision.
Vents frustration about poor intelligence after learning the Japanese fleet position was misreported, showing critical awareness of operational challenges.
Rebukes Lindsey harshly for endangering the carrier and shirking duty, showing intolerance for irresponsibility and cowardice.
Avoids escalating confrontation despite strong anger, walks away after McClusky intervenes.
Expresses anger and pain upon hearing likely death of Cliff; accepts and appreciates Ann's comforting touch.
Shows concern for his family’s safety by urging wife and daughter to go to her parents' place, despite her refusal.
Respects wife's firm decision and ultimately agrees, showing tolerance and respect for her autonomy.
Shrugs off Murray's concern with a grim refusal to be a POW and tells Murray to cover him with guns, showing blunt resolve but little reassurance or encouragement.
Obliviously swings up into the cockpit after giving harsh words to Murray, indicating a focus on mission rather than emotional support.
Calmly coordinates with his rear gunner despite incoming enemy fighters, showing trust and teamwork.
Focuses intensely on mission objectives under heavy fire without visible concern for personal safety or team morale.
Commands Murray in a terse manner to 'Get those bastards off me,' which could be seen as brusque or lacking friendliness.

Shoves throttle forward and dives at terminal velocity despite heavy flak, maintains control under intense pressure, executes precise bomb release, pulls out of dive close to ground, successfully destroys enemy hangar and bombers.
Lines up gunsight and fires accurately at an enemy fighter passing at high speed, causing visible damage despite being attacked by multiple enemy fighters immediately afterward.
Squeezes Ann's shoulder and offers her a drink, responding warmly to her suggestion to dance.
Responds to Layton's offer with a flat tone and an insulting comment about Fleet Intelligence's drinking habits.
Abruptly bursts into the room and delivers a confident, no-nonsense speech to nervous pilots, showing leadership and clarity of mission.
Directly tells new pilots he doesn’t have time to coddle them and must ensure they are competent, demonstrating high standards and understanding of the stakes.
Notices a pilot's shallow approach but acknowledges his successful correction and safe landing, then makes a confident decision to include the pilot in the rotation.
Dismisses pilots brusquely and makes light of his own reputation as a tough XO.
Challenges Willie's confidence harshly, questioning his motives in a way that insults him.
Pushes Willie to overcome his fears by emphasizing duty and seriousness of the situation.
Recognizes he may have pushed Willie too hard and immediately offers to make him his wingman, providing support.
Doubles scouting flights and emphasizes practice to prepare the squadron for upcoming battles, demonstrating foresight and leadership.
Challenges a struggling pilot's confidence sharply but then offers support by making him his wingman, showing both tough leadership and mentorship.
Rolls his eyes at Dickinson's behavior, indicating mild impatience or frustration but does not undermine authority.
Watches friend Willie crash into the ocean and urgently radios rescue crew to hurry.
Expresses anger and frustration by slamming fist on cockpit at tragedy.
Engages in casual, confident conversation with fellow pilots, showing camaraderie and understanding of squadron capabilities.
Acknowledges the flaws and dangers of torpedo bombers realistically, indicating awareness of operational challenges.
Lies with his head on Ann's lap, showing vulnerability and seeking comfort.
Admits to having written a letter to a mother telling her he failed her son, showing sincerity and accountability.
Expresses deep worry and emotional pain about losing men, demonstrating empathy and care for his comrades.
Mentions taking a nervous new pilot under his wing, indicating a willingness to support and nurture others.
Comparing himself harshly to his XO and acknowledging that pushing someone too hard can be damaging, signaling reflection and learning.
Opens up emotionally and admits to worries about leading the squadron, showing vulnerability and sincerity.
Shares a tender moment with Ann, receiving her support and responding with visible relief and appreciation.
Expresses self-doubt about leading the squadron but confronts it honestly and seeks reassurance from Ann.
Demonstrates emotional honesty and openness in admitting worries, showing self-awareness but not direct skill or confident leadership in this moment.
Shares a slight smile after Dickinson praises intel, showing quiet confidence and approachability.
Engages in a candid conversation with Dickinson about the mission and morale, showing concern for motivating his men.
Reflects seriously on how to get the men to believe in him and the mission, indicating self-awareness and care for his comrades' trust.
Pours over tactical charts to understand enemy positions and strategize.
Acknowledges the poor odds honestly but maintains optimism and focus on surprise.
Seeks advice on leadership and motivating men to believe in the mission and him.
Shows doubt and questions how to inspire confidence in his men, indicating some uncertainty.
Relaxes with Dickinson seeing the Yorktown returned, showing confident poise despite uncertainty.
Shrugs at Yorktown returning but shows relief on his face, indicating emotional control and situational awareness.
Carefully inspects every rivet and seam on the plane, showing meticulous attention to detail and responsibility towards equipment readiness.

Offers encouraging, realistic, and confident speech to fellow pilots, bolstering morale before battle.
Shares personal story with emotional weight to build camaraderie and fortify collective resolve.

Shows frustration but openly communicates his oxygen issue to Murray, signaling trust and openness.

Prepares to fly his plane by revving engine and fastening oxygen mask confidently before takeoff.

Flies with one hand on the stick while holding binoculars with the other, actively searching the ocean and assessing situation.
Questions the accuracy of the sighting report and considers alternate possibilities for the enemy movement.
Motivates squadron with confident and collective 'It's payback time' statement.
Focuses on tactical attack and mission fulfilment without personal warmth expression.
Checks on wingman Murray's status and shows concern by asking if any fighters are on their tail.
Enters the Enterprise bridge promptly to report on the situation, calmly delivers critical information about the enemy and losses despite bad news.
Approaches targets aggressively, quickly transitions to new target after shooting down a bomber without hesitation.
Remains calm and focused despite running out of ammo at a critical moment, showing situational awareness and restraint.
Participates in reporting status of engagement accurately to Rear Admiral Spruance, demonstrating leadership and communication skills.
Responds promptly and respectfully to Spruance's order to put trusted pilots into flyable planes.
Despite physical exhaustion and illness (coughing), pushes himself to continue the mission and rallies the remaining pilots to attack again.

Faces the grim reality of losses without showing defeat, encouraging others to continue the fight.
